item.value:
Encapsulates a Java {@link java.lang.reflect.Type}, providing access to {@link getSuperType() supertypes}, {@link getInterfaces() interfaces}, and {@link getGeneric(int...) generic parameters} along with the ability to ultimately {@link resolve() resolve} to a {@link java.lang.Class}.

{@code ResolvableTypes} may be obtained from {@link forField(Field) fields}, {@link forMethodParameter(Method, int) method parameters}, {@link forMethodReturnType(Method) method returns} or {@link forClass(Class) classes}. Most methods on this class will themselves return {@link ResolvableType ResolvableTypes}, allowing easy navigation. For example: 

 private HashMap<Integer, List<String>> myMap; public void example() { ResolvableType t = ResolvableType.forField(getClass().getDeclaredField("myMap")); t.getSuperType(); AbstractMap<Integer, List<String>> t.asMap(); Map<Integer, List<String>> t.getGeneric(0).resolve(); Integer t.getGeneric(1).resolve(); List t.getGeneric(1); List<String> t.resolveGeneric(1, 0); String }

A BeanDefinition describes a bean instance, which has property values, constructor argument values, and further information supplied by concrete implementations. This is just a minimal interface: The main intention is to allow a BeanFactoryPostProcessor to introspect and modify property values and other bean metadata.

Instruments the application startup phase using steps. The core container and its infrastructure components can use the ApplicationStartup to mark steps during the application startup and collect data about the execution context or their processing time.
